answer_html: \(\left\{\begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} \text{ such that } \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix}=s (v_2 + v_3) \text{ for some } s \in \mathbb{R}\right\}\)
answer_latex: $\left\{\begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} \text{ such that } \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix}=s (v_2 + v_3) \text{ for some } s \in \mathbb{R}\right\}$
hints_html: For a real matrix, if \(\displaystyle v\) is an eigenvector to a complex eigenvalue \(\displaystyle \lambda\), then \(\displaystyle \overline v\) is an eigenvector to a complex eigenvalue \(\displaystyle \overline \lambda\)
hints_latex:
For a real matrix, if $\displaystyle v$ is an eigenvector to a complex
eigenvalue $\displaystyle \lambda$, then $\displaystyle \overline v$ is
an eigenvector to a complex eigenvalue $\displaystyle \overline \lambda$
hints_raw: For a real matrix, if <math>\displaystyle v</math> is an eigenvector to a complex eigenvalue <math>\displaystyle \lambda</math>, then <math>\displaystyle \overline v</math> is an eigenvector to a complex eigenvalue <math>\displaystyle \overline \lambda</math>
question: 5 (c)
sols_html:
For real matrices, just as complex eigenvalues, also complex eigenvectors come in conjugate pairs. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle v_2 = \overline{v_3}\end{aligned}\]

Hence v2 + v3 is a real vector and therefore we ensure that the solution vector [c, b, a]T in part (b) is real by choosing real coefficients s and t and setting s = t:

\[\begin{aligned} \left\{\begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} \text{ such that } \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = s (v_2 + v_3) \text{ for some } s \in \mathbb{R}\right\}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
For real matrices, just as complex eigenvalues, also complex eigenvectors come in conjugate pairs. Hence

:<math> \displaystyle
v_2 = \overline{v_3}
</math>

Hence ''v<sub>2</sub> + v<sub>3</sub>'' is a real vector and therefore we ensure that the solution vector ''[c, b, a]<sup>T</sub>'' in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_05_(b)|part (b)]] is real by choosing real coefficients ''s'' and ''t'' and setting ''s = t'':

:<math>
\left\{\begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} \text{ such that } \begin{bmatrix} c \\ b \\ a \end{bmatrix} = s (v_2 + v_3) \text{ for some } s \in \mathbb{R}\right\}
</math>
statement_html:
Define a sequence x0, x1, ... by the initial conditions x0 = a, x1 = b and x2 = c together with the recursion relation

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle x_{n+3} = x_{n+2} + x_{n+1} + x_n\end{aligned}\]

for n = 0, 1, 2, ...

(c) Explain how you could ensure that the a, b and c you find in part (b) are real numbers.
statement_latex:
Define a sequence \emph{x}\textsubscript{0}, \emph{x}\textsubscript{1},
... by the initial conditions \emph{x}\textsubscript{0} = \emph{a},
\emph{x}\textsubscript{1} = \emph{b} and \emph{x}\textsubscript{2} =
\emph{c} together with the recursion relation

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
x_{n+3} = x_{n+2} + x_{n+1} + x_n
\end{align*}

for \emph{n} = 0, 1, 2, ...

\textbf{(c)} Explain how you could ensure that the \emph{a}, \emph{b}
and \emph{c} you find in
{part
(b)} are real numbers.
statement_raw:
Define a sequence ''x''<sub>0</sub>, ''x''<sub>1</sub>, ... by the initial conditions ''x''<sub>0</sub> = ''a'', ''x''<sub>1</sub> = ''b'' and ''x''<sub>2</sub> = ''c'' together with the recursion relation

:<math> \displaystyle
x_{n+3} = x_{n+2} + x_{n+1} + x_n
</math>

for ''n'' = 0, 1, 2, ...

'''(c)''' Explain how you could ensure that the ''a'', ''b'' and ''c'' you find in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_05_(b)|part (b)]] are real numbers.
